div.head: Kat River.—Mission to the Bushmen
div.p: The friends of religion and humanity will rejoice to learn that means have been taken to impart the blessings of the Gospel to the abject and destitute Bushmen in the vicinity of the Kat River Settlement. About the beginning of last year, a member of the Mission church (a person of Bushman origin having at one of the religious meetings expressed a great concern for the scattered remnant of his father's nation, the subject excited deep interest in the minds of all present, and after due deliberation, a Mission, to consist of native teachers, was resolved upon. The accomplishment of this benevolent design, with the preparatory proceedins, is described in letters received under various dates from teh Rev. James Read. His first allusion to the subject, contained in a letter dated in May last, is as follows :—

My son has lately been out with several others to look for Bushmen, and to select a spot for a station. A number more are expected to join. These poor creatures are in a most deplorable condition, without houses, clothing, or any property whatever. They were highly pleased at the prospect of having the word of God among them. There are many more of them in the mountains and caves, and it is the Gospel only which will bring them from their places of refuge, from wild beasts and wild men. Poor Madoor and his people say that they have begin to think that they belong to the human race, because there are men who appear to be concerned about them. May God extend his mercy to those poor outcasts!

Under date, August 14, Mr. Read thus continues his statements relative to the Busman Mission, noticing also the commencement of efforts of a similar kind on behalf of a number of natives belonging to the Tambookie tribe of Caffres :—

In a former communication, I mentioned the desire some of our people had expressed to do something for the poor Bushmen, Tambookies, &c. They had intended to execute their wishes long before the present time, but the measles retarded the undertaking. Now, however, by the blessing of God, nearly all in the settlement who had been affected by this disorder have recovered, and the first thing to be attempted is the accomplishment of this work. Four native brethren have been chosen, two for the Bushmen, and two for the Tambookie Chief, Kallagalla. With those for the Bushmen, four native brethren will be associated as assistants, to be employed in cultivating the ground, building houses, &c. The first thing thought of, after the Bible and Missionaries, was a plough; the Bible in one hand, and the plough in the other. It is by such means as these the curse is removed, the earth yields her increase, the thorn and brier is not only figuratively but literally removed; and if the fir-tree and myrtle do not come up in their place, we shall have the peach, apple, fig, pear, and grape.

To obtain the plough a subscription was proposed, and one engaged to give a plough-share, another the coulter, another the wheels; others contributed other parts, and now the plough is standing ready. Considerable interest has been excited, and although our people are suffering greatly from poverty, partly from the effects of the late war, and partly from the failure of their last harvest, yet they have given, we may say, beyond their power; all seemed ansious to bring a small offering for the brethren and the Bushmen; event the children of the infant school came, one with a spoon, another with a knife, or something else they had importuned from their parents; so that my room is actually full of articles of various descriptions, such as seed, wheat, barley, Indian corn, pumpkin-seed, potatoes, beans, peas, vegetable seed; a few old clothes; basons basins , plates, spoons, knives, forks, spades, pickaces, axes, &c. We had also a collection on Sunday week, and received the sum of 13l. A span of oxen has been presented; and finding a wagon would be necessary, a subscription was proposed, and immediately upwards of 22l. was subscribed towards it. The day after to-morrow it is intended, with the will of God, that the brethren leave. I, with one of our deacons, a field-cornet, and others, will accompany them to see them settled, assit them in putting up temporary houses, getting out the water, ploughing, &c. It is just the time for ploughing and sowing. Thus we are lengthening our cords as well as strengthening our stakes, and we trust we shall out on the right hand and on the left.

In almost every portion of the Missionary field there are indications of the

Already much has been effected by this species of instrumentality in the South Seas; and we trust, ere long, to witness far larger and more delightful results from the augmented attention now being paid by our Missionary brethren to the training of teachers from among their converst, so that the piety and talent of their churches may be called forth and suitably applied. It is a source of rejoicing that Africa is also yeilding her share of similar fruits. The annexed plate is inteded to represent a highly delightful and exhibilarting scene, as described by the Rev. Mr. Read, of the Kat River settlement. Boosman, an old Hottentot disciple, had been introduced to Kallagalla, a Tambookie Chief, and after opening his heart, full of holly affection adn ardent aspirations, he followed the Chief. We give the scene in Mr. Read's own graphic language :—

I returned from my journey the day before yesterday; by the blessing of God I was able to accomplish all we wished and prayed for. We left two native teachers with Kallagalla, the Tambookie chief, on the Kei River; we left them without gold or silver, purse or scrip, or two coats, without a wagon, and with only about a pail of millet, and a pound of coffee. They had no expectation of getting any thing from the Tambookies. You would have been pleased with the first interview. Boosman, one of the teachers, and old Hottentot disciple, wept when he saw Kallagalla, and said, "Kallagalla, my heart opens now that I see you; I thank God that he has brought me to you, and I give myself up to serve you; where you flee I'll flee, whether in the mountain, plain, or river; where you die I am ready to die. I am come to you to show you and your people the way to heaven, and you can know by me that God is no respecter of persons; for as you see I am one of the most despicable and unseemly of mankind, but God has opened my heart and given me to see the way of salvation through Jesus Christ his Son, and now my desire is that you and all men may hear the joyful news and be saved." I shall never forget his leaving us, trudging after the chief with his blanket on his shoulders, and sincing and weeping as he went.

Three weeks after, on our return to the place, we found them labouring in season and out of season, going from kraal to kraal, making known the Saviour. Kallagalla wishes to have the water out upon his ground. I hope our people will assist him.

We went on forty miles further, but on account of the state of the country did not succeed in finding the Bushman Chief, Madoor, in less than twelve days, but we fixed upon a spot, and commenced working; for although we have have not a Missionary ship, we have a Missionary plough, and hope at last to have a Missionary wagon. We got out the water from a fountain, cultivated a large extent of land, sowed a half a sack of ppotatoes, some barley, wheat, beans, peas, Caffre-corn, and millet, all for the poor Bushmen. I never worked harder in my life, nor with greater pleasure. You might have seen me sometimes with the axe, sometimes with the spade, and sometimes holding the plough, and I had strength equal to my day. We built two temporary houses. At last Madoor and some of his people made their appearance, and the Queen of Sheba could scarcely be more happily surprised than Madoor was, at seeing what was doing for him. Next morning we dressed him in a suit of clothes, which the people of Kat River had sent for him, and he at once underwent a most pleasing transformation, and appeared delighted beyond measure. "I always said," observed Madoor, "that I had friends who would one day make their appearance."

We left him three native brethren, and a boy, one as a native teacher, and two to cultivate the land, build houses, &c. We left them with few clothes, little food, no wagon, and wanting many things which an English Missionary would require. May the Lord follow up with his blessing our poor weak endeavours.

I had a pious band with me. We had prayer-meetings morning and evening, and our great Zerubbabel made mountains become plains. Simply as we go to work, this undertaking costs us considerably more than we can spare. I hope you will set a subscription on foot for us to help this good work.
